quoteTime: About three o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: the steersman signaled a large four-mast steamer, which slightly changed its course, in order to give the “Great Eastern” its number. It was the “Atlanta,” one of the largest boats running between London and New York, calling at Brest on the way.
title: A Floating City, and The Blockade Runners
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905

quoteFirst: They now had a good view of the gorge, and it was so full of obstructions—tangled thickets, fallen trees and boulders that had tumbled from the cliffs above—and the path was so narrow and winding, that it was a mystery to them how the horses could have found their way through there in the dark. They stopped once for a short rest and lunch, and
quoteTime: about three o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: arrived within sight of the prairie. They thought of the wild man, but saw no signs of him.
title: Snowed Up; or, The Sportman's Club in the Mountains
author: Castlemon, Harry, 1842-1915

quoteLast: that he mounted his stairs. In his mood, brooding over the new-found tragedies, it seemed quite natural, and a thing to be expected, that his cousin Mary Anne should be sitting on the stairs opposite his closed door. She rose timidly.
title: The Fourth Generation
author: Besant, Walter, 1836-1901

quoteLast: , the two barges sent from the capital came alongside. The mandarin who commanded them was the finest figure of a man we had yet seen since we entered the country.
title: The Mission to Siam, and Hué, the Capital of Cochin China, in the Years 1821-2
author: Finlayson, George, 1790-1823

quoteFirst: Tarleton, who had never ceased to press forward, came upon Buford’s rear-guard
quoteTime: about three o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , and captured a sergeant and four dragoons. Buford had not expected so prompt an approach of the enemy.
title: Life of George Washington, volume 4 of 5
author: Irving, Washington, 1783-1859

quoteFirst: We lay upon our arms in line of battle, ready and impatient to take part in the contest, listening to the roar of battle in the distance. General Smith, our division commander,
quoteTime: about three o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: received orders to advance upon the enemy in our front, and immediately our attacking force was formed by Lauman's brigade, in column of regiments, consisting of the Twenty-fifth Indiana, and three Iowa regiments, General Smith himself leading the attack.
title: War Stories for my Grandchildren
author: Foster, John Watson, 1836-1917

quoteFirst: While he was thus awaiting the arrival of the marquis, a carriage that had left the château
quoteTime: about three o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: paused at the intersection of the footpath not far from the so-called Grand Sire's Rock.
title: The Seven Cardinal Sins: Envy and Indolence
author: Sue, Eugène, 1804-1857; Marcel, Adrian [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Sulieman, where we were landed at
quoteLast: . I made a part of the passage on the deck of the U boat, and had some little chat with its commander. He admitted that we had nearly put his "eye" out with one of our shells.

quoteFirst: See two sights of this land, Table 6 Numbers 2 and 3. We could not stem the tide till
quoteLast: ; when, the tide running with us, we soon got abreast of the bay, and then saw a small island to the eastward of us. See a sight of it Table 6 Number 4. About 6 we anchored in the bottom of the bay in 25 fathom, soft oaze, half a mile from the shore.
title: A Continuation of a Voyage to New Holland, Etc. in the Year 1699
